unmortgaged properties even if another property in that color-group is 
mortgaged. 
It is even more advantageous to have houses or hotels on properties 
because rents are much higher than for unimproved properties. 
The owner may not collect the rent if he/she fails to ask for it before 
the second player following throws the dice. 
"CHANCE" AND "COMMUNITY CHEST": When you land on either of 
these spaces, take the top card from the deck indicated, follow the

[DOC 2 | monopoly.pdf | page 6]
reverse of the manner in which they were erected. 
MORTGAGES: Unimproved properties can be mortgaged through the 
Bank at any time. Before an improved property can be mortgaged, all 
the buildings on all the properties of its color-group must be sold back 
to the Bank at half price. The mortgage value is printed on each Title 
Deed card. 
No rent can be collected on mortgaged properties or utilities, 
but rent can be collected on unmortgaged properties in the 
same group. 
In order to lift the mortgage, the owner must pay the Bank the 
amount of the mortgage plus 10% interest. When all the propert~es of 
a color-group are no longer mortgaged, the owner may begin t

question: How is rent affected by owning all properties in a color group?
reference_answer: Rent is doubled on unimproved properties when a player owns all properties in a color group.
model_answer: According to the context, if a player owns all the properties in a color group, they can charge double rent for unimproved properties in that color group, even if another property in that group is mortgaged.

correctness.justification: Model answer is mostly correct, but lacks precision in mentioning 'even if another property in that group is mortgaged' which is not explicitly stated in the reference answer.

groundedness.justification: The model answer is fully supported by the provided context, which explicitly states that a player can charge double rent for unimproved properties in a color group if they own all the properties in that group, even if another property in the group is mortgaged.

relevance.justification: The answer directly addresses the effect of owning all properties in a color group on rent, specifying the double rent rule for unimproved properties in that group.

question: What happens if you donâ€™t have enough cash to pay a debt?
reference_answer: You must mortgage properties or sell houses/hotels to raise the funds. If you still can't pay, youâ€™re bankrupt.
model_answer: According to the provided context, if you don't have enough cash to pay a debt, you must turn over all assets to the Bank. In this case, the Bank immediately sells by auction all property so taken, except buildings. A bankrupt player must immediately retire from the game.

relevance.justification: The answer is completely off-topic, as it appears to be discussing a game and the concept of bankruptcy, but the question is asking about a real-world scenario where someone lacks the cash to pay a debt.
